title: Contribution Guidelines
text: contributions welcome. Thank contributing! several ways contribute:

title: Contribution Guidelines
text: Open issue report bug (typo), suggest feature request, get help (yes, need go Stack Overflow, get help author directly issue becomes tutorial others!). opening issue, try include reprex, minimally reproducible example can replicated one base datasets R, mtcars dataset. make reprex, consider using reprex package. takes bit time get used , useful!

what: Pro Tip on Creating a Reprex FAST
title: Contribution Guidelines
text: ’s quality life upgrade learned late regarding reprexes. Instead loading package library(reprex), copying code Ctrl+c typing reprex() console, faster way. install package first time, actually adds addin RStudio. Simply click Addins button Help menu, search bar type reprex select Render reprex... ’ve copied relevant code. opens reprex window can specify different options finally click blue Render button render reprex. cool also allows easily add session info reprex checking Append session info check box. wait, way make even faster! Make addin selection shortcut (example) Ctrl+r going Tools, Modify Keyboard Shortcuts..., search bar type reprex, Render reprex... row, click Shortcut column, type desired shortcut (use Ctrl+r). , copy code Ctr+c, open reprex addin window Ctrl+r, press tab 3 times press enter. BAM! reprex < 5 seconds.

title: Contribution Guidelines
text: Start discussion discuss ideas, organization, meta-ideas, ask questions, create polls, anything else doesn’t fit well issue.

title: Contribution Guidelines
text: Submit PR (’ve never heard term , ’s Pull Request!). essentially means make code contribution package repository. ’s complicated , don’t worry, can just copy-paste code contribution issue add . bit experienced however, suggested submit PR. recommended workflow submit PR following. Fork repository (use: usethis::create_from_github("rempsyc/rempsyc")). Create branch (RStudio, click tiny purple flowchart Git tab, blue wheel main branch buttons), name based theme suggested changes. Commit push (Ctrl+p) changes branch RStudio. Submit PR modified branch (go branch GitHub website, automatically suggest open PR draft message ). Include one reprexes showing old new behaviour comparison. Note using usethis steps, need : installed git software (.e., R package); created github token usethis::create_github_token() (see usethis::gh_token_help() help); set credentials gitcreds::gitcreds_set().

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: recently discovered wonderful package easily checking linear regression assumptions via diagnostic plots: check_model() function performance package. Let’s make quick demonstration package first.  Wonderful! efficient. However, sometimes, different reasons, someone might want check assumptions objective test. Testing assumption one one kind time-consuming, made convenience function accelerate process. Just warning jumping objective assumption tests. Note tests generally recommended! large sample size, objective assumption tests -sensitive deviations expected values, small sample size, objective assumption tests -powered detect real, existing deviations. can also mask visual patterns reflected single number. thus recommended use visual assessment diagnostic plots instead (e.g., see Shatz, 2023, Kozak & Piepho, 2018, https://doi.org/10.1111/jac.12220; Schucany & Ng, 2006). quick accessible argument tests normality specifically, see source.
code: # Load necessary libraries library(performance) library(see) # Note: if you haven't installed the packages above, # you'll need to install them first by using: # install_if_not_installed(c("performance", "see"))  # Create a regression model (using data available in R by default) model <- lm(mpg ~ wt * cyl + gear, data = mtcars) # Check model assumptions check_model(model)

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: install.packages("rempsyc"). Furthermore, may asked install following packages haven’t installed already (may decide install now avoid interrupting workflow wish follow tutorial beginning end): raw output doesn’t look nice console column names long, look good viewer exported word processing software column names get wrapped. can try RStudio following command:  Model Normality (Shapiro-Wilk) Homoscedasticity (Breusch-Pagan) Autocorrelation residuals (Durbin-Watson) Diagnostic mpg ~ wt * cyl + gear .615 .054 .525 0.00 Interpretation: (p) values < .05 imply assumptions respected. Diagnostic many assumptions respected given model variable. function particularly useful testing several models simultaneously makes nice table results. Let’s make short demonstration . Use Viewer better results  alternatively nice_table() function Model Normality (Shapiro-Wilk) Homoscedasticity (Breusch-Pagan) Autocorrelation residuals (Durbin-Watson) Diagnostic cyl ~ mpg .361 .282 .460 0.00 disp ~ mpg .506 .831 .077 0.00 hp ~ mpg .004** .351 .198 1.00 drat ~ mpg .939 .887 .505 0.00 wt ~ mpg .020* .270 .002** 2.00 qsec ~ mpg .427 .944 .011* 1.00 vs ~ mpg .142 .568 .238 0.00 ~ mpg .074 .650 < .001*** 1.00 gear ~ mpg .001** .528 < .001*** 2.00 carb ~ mpg .008** .362 .003** 2.00
code: library(rempsyc) pkgs <- c(   "flextable", "performance", "see", "lmtest", "ggplot2",   "qqplotr", "ggrepel", "patchwork", "boot" ) install_if_not_installed(pkgs) View(nice_assumptions(model)) nice_table(nice_assumptions(model), col.format.p = 2:4) # Define our dependent variables DV <- names(mtcars[-1]) # Make list of all formulas formulas <- paste(DV, "~ mpg") # Make list of all models models.list <- lapply(X = formulas, FUN = lm, data = mtcars) # Make diagnostic table assumptions.table <- nice_assumptions(models.list) View(assumptions.table) nice_table(assumptions.table, col.format.p = 2:4)

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: categorical predictors (e.g., groups), suggested check assumptions directly raw data rather residuals (source). case, one can make qqplots different groups first check normality assumption.

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Generally speaking, long dots lie within confidence band, good data distribute normally.
code: nice_qq(   data = iris,   variable = "Sepal.Length",   group = "Species" )

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Change (reorder) colours, x-axis title y-axis title, names groups, grid lines, add p-value Shapiro-Wilk (wish ).  p > .05 suggests data normally distributed (according Shapiro-Wilk test). Inversely, p < .05 suggests data normally distributed. Keep mind however several known problems objective tests, visual assessment recommended. Nonetheless, beginners, can sometimes useful (rather, reassuring) able pair visual assessment tests values.
code: nice_qq(   data = iris,   variable = "Sepal.Length",   group = "Species",   colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),   groups.labels = c("(a) Setosa", "(b) Versicolor", "(c) Virginica"),   grid = FALSE,   shapiro = TRUE,   title = NULL )

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: people think density distributions less useful qqplots, sometimes, people still like look distributions, made another function .

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Pro tip: Save density plots narrower width better-looking results.
code: nice_density(   data = iris,   variable = "Sepal.Length",   group = "Species" )

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Change (reorder) colours, x-axis title y-axis title, names groups, grid lines, add p-value Shapiro-Wilk (wish ).
code: nice_density(   data = iris,   variable = "Sepal.Length",   group = "Species",   colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),   xtitle = "Sepal Length",   ytitle = "Density (vs. Normal Distribution)",   groups.labels = c("(a) Setosa", "(b) Versicolor", "(c) Virginica"),   grid = FALSE,   shapiro = TRUE,   histogram = TRUE,   title = "Density (Sepal Length)" )

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Finally, also possible combine plot types single function, nice_normality.
code: nice_normality(   data = iris,   variable = "Sepal.Length",   group = "Species",   shapiro = TRUE,   histogram = TRUE,   title = "Density (Sepal Length)" )

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: check outliers categorical predictors, can check group whether observations greater 3 units. default uses median absolute deviations (MADs, method = "mad"), based following publication: Leys, C., Klein, O., Bernard, P., & Licata, L. (2013). Detecting outliers: use standard deviation around mean, use absolute deviation around median. Journal Experimental Social Psychology, 49(4), 764–766. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jesp.2013.03.013

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: aware checking outliers group group yield different results, e.g.,:
code: plot_outliers(   airquality,   group = "Month",   response = "Ozone" ) plot_outliers(   airquality,   response = "Ozone" )

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Change (reorder) colours, y-axis title, names groups, detection method.
code: plot_outliers(   airquality,   group = "Month",   response = "Ozone",   method = "sd",   criteria = 3.29,   colours = c("white", "black", "purple", "grey", "pink"),   ytitle = "Ozone",   xtitle = "Month of the Year" )

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Outliers can also identifed find_mad multiple variables:
code: find_mad(airquality, names(airquality), criteria = 3) ## 8 outlier(s) based on 3 median absolute deviations for variable(s):  ##  Ozone, Solar.R, Wind, Temp, Month, Day  ##  ## Outliers per variable:  ##  ## $Ozone ##   Row Ozone_mad ## 1  30  3.218284 ## 2  62  3.989131 ## 3  99  3.488081 ## 4 101  3.025573 ## 5 117  5.261028 ## 6 121  3.333911 ##  ## $Wind ##   Row Wind_mad ## 1   9 3.049871 ## 2  48 3.225825

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Outliers can also winsorized winsorize_mad, meaning outlier values outside 3 MADs brought back 3 MADs:

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: multivariate outliers, recommended use Minimum Covariance Determinant (MCD), available performance package easystats mentioned beginning post. note also ideally handling outliers preregistered priori. --date recommendations handling outliers, please see: Leys, C., Delacre, M., Mora, Y. L., Lakens, D., & Ley, C. (2019). classify, detect, manage univariate multivariate outliers, emphasis pre-registration. International Review Social Psychology, 32(1). https://doi.org/10.5334/irsp.289
code: check_outliers(na.omit(airquality), method = "mcd") ## 7 outliers detected: cases 6, 7, 11, 14, 23, 34, 77. ## - Based on the following method and threshold: mcd (22.458). ## - For variables: Ozone, Solar.R, Wind, Temp, Month, Day.

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: check homoscedasticity (equality variance) categorical predictors, can check variance within group. can use rule thumb variance one group four times another group. can check function makes table.

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Let’s now try many variables see handy can . Use Viewer better results (export Word using nice_table() function)
code: View(nice_var(   data = iris,   variable = "Sepal.Length",   group = "Species" )) # Define our dependent variables DV <- names(iris[1:4])  # Make diagnostic table var.table <- nice_var(   data = iris,   variable = DV,   group = "Species" ) View(var.table)

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: can also interesting look variance visually learning purposes.

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
code: nice_varplot(   data = iris,   variable = "Sepal.Length",   group = "Species" )

title: Quickly test linear regression assumptions
text: Change (reorder) colours, y-axis title, names groups.
code: nice_varplot(   data = iris,   variable = "Sepal.Length",   group = "Species",   colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),   ytitle = "Sepal Length",   groups.labels = c("(a) Setosa", "(b) Versicolor", "(c) Virginica") )

title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: post, document conduct planned contrasts analyses test whether experimental groups differ . Planned contrasts similar t tests, provide power several groups: Statistical power lower standard t test compared planned contrast version two reasons: ) sample size smaller t test, cases two groups selected; b) planned contrast error term smaller standard t test based cases (source) first demonstrate simple example conducting analysis, exporting table results Microsoft Word, producing figure. demonstrating single variable, look full workflow, .e., can automatize process several variables simultaneously.

title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: minimal example, use iris dataset, installed R default.

title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: install.packages("rempsyc"). Furthermore, may asked install following packages haven’t installed already (may decide install now avoid interrupting workflow wish follow tutorial beginning end): Let’s test function existing data give us Cohen’s d default effect size, possible request ‘robust’ version (.e., robust deviations parametric assumptions) Cohen’s d specifying effect.type = "akp.robust.d". also provide us bootstrapped 95% confidence intervals effect size.
code: library(rempsyc) pkgs <- c(   "bootES", "emmeans", "flextable", "ggplot2", "boot",   "ggsignif", "ggpubr" ) install_if_not_installed(pkgs) set.seed(100) table.stats <- nice_contrasts(   response = "Sepal.Length",   group = "Species",   data = iris ) table.stats ##   Dependent Variable             Comparison  df          t            p ## 1       Sepal.Length    setosa - versicolor 147  -9.032819 8.770194e-16 ## 2       Sepal.Length     setosa - virginica 147 -15.365506 2.214821e-32 ## 3       Sepal.Length versicolor - virginica 147  -6.332686 2.765638e-09 ##           d CI_lower   CI_upper ## 1 -1.806564 -2.17235 -1.4111701 ## 2 -3.073101 -3.52209 -2.4497683 ## 3 -1.266537 -1.71202 -0.7930314

title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: Dependent Variable Comparison df t p d 95% CI Sepal.Length setosa - versicolor 147 -9.03 < .001*** -1.81 [-2.17, -1.41] setosa - virginica 147 -15.37 < .001*** -3.07 [-3.52, -2.45] versicolor - virginica 147 -6.33 < .001*** -1.27 [-1.71, -0.79] Open (save) table Word

title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: full workflow, use dataset one studies published Quarterly Journal Experimental Psychology (https://doi.org/10.1177/17470218211024826) available Open Science Framework. Load data file Open Science Framework Specify order factor levels “Group” (otherwise R alphabetize ) Define dependent variables Add meaningful names measures
code: data <- read.csv("https://osf.io/qkmnp//?action=download", header = TRUE) (data$Group <- factor(data$Group, levels = c("Embodied", "Mental", "Control"))) ##  [1] Embodied Embodied Control  Control  Mental   Embodied Control  Control  ##  [9] Control  Embodied Mental   Mental   Control  Control  Mental   Control  ## [17] Mental   Mental   Embodied Embodied Control  Embodied Mental   Control  ## [25] Embodied Embodied Mental   Control  Mental   Embodied Embodied Mental   ## [33] Mental   Mental   Embodied Mental   Embodied Mental   Control  Embodied ## [41] Mental   Mental   Embodied Mental   Mental   Embodied Control  Control  ## [49] Control  Mental   Embodied Control  Embodied Control  Mental   Embodied ## [57] Embodied Embodied Control  Control  Control  Control  Mental   Control  ## [65] Mental   Embodied Embodied Mental   Embodied Control  Control  Mental   ## [73] Mental   Control  Control  Embodied Mental   Control  Embodied Embodied ## [81] Embodied Mental   Control  Control  Embodied Mental   Mental   Mental   ## [89] Embodied Control  ## Levels: Embodied Mental Control library(dplyr) (DV <- data %>% select(QCAEPR:IOS) %>% names()) ## [1] "QCAEPR" "IRIPT"  "IRIFS"  "IRIEC"  "IRIPD"  "IOS" set.seed(100) table.stats <- nice_contrasts(   response = DV,   group = "Group",   data = data ) table.stats ##    Dependent Variable         Comparison df           t            p ## 1              QCAEPR  Embodied - title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: Note option highlight = TRUE, automatically highlight significant results. Table 1 Results multiple regression planned contrasts analyses empathy subscales self–merging (confirmatory analyses exception self–merging) Dependent Variable Comparison df t p d 95% CI Peripheral Responsivity (QCAE) Embodied - Mental 87 1.96 .053 0.51 [0.04, 0.98] Embodied - Control 87 2.20 .031* 0.57 [0.00, 1.10] Mental - Control 87 0.24 .813 0.06 [-0.50, 0.58] Perspective-Taking (IRI) Embodied - Mental 86 0.10 .919 0.03 [-0.47, 0.52] Embodied - Control 86 0.12 .903 0.03 [-0.52, 0.59] Mental - Control 86 0.02 .985 0.01 [-0.47, 0.52] Fantasy (IRI) Embodied - Mental 86 1.54 .128 0.40 [-0.11, 0.92] Embodied - Control 86 0.15 .880 0.04 [-0.47, 0.58] Mental - Control 86 -1.39 .169 -0.36 [-0.88, 0.14] Empathic Concern (IRI) Embodied - Mental 86 0.83 .407 0.22 [-0.28, 0.73] Embodied - Control 86 2.30 .024* 0.59 [0.06, 1.13] Mental - Control 86 1.45 .151 0.38 [-0.14, 0.91] Personal Distress (IRI) Embodied - Mental 86 1.25 .213 0.33 [-0.23, 0.87] Embodied - Control 86 2.13 .036* 0.55 [0.04, 1.07] Mental - Control 86 0.86 .393 0.22 [-0.27, 0.68] Inclusion Self (IOS) Embodied - Mental 87 2.58 .011* 0.67 [0.11, 1.17] Embodied - Control 87 4.71 < .001*** 1.22 [0.63, 1.73] Mental - Control 87 2.12 .037* 0.55 [0.05, 1.04] Note. 𝑑ᴿ = robust Cohen’s 𝑑; CI = bootstrapped confidence interval. comparisons -groups (.e., within-subject pre/post comparisons). One participant complete Interpersonal Reactivity Index. Bold/Grey background values represent statistically significant differences groups row variable. Open (save) table Word
code: (my_table <- nice_table(table.stats,   highlight = TRUE,   title = c("Table 1", "Results of multiple regression with planned contrasts analyses for empathy subscales and self–other merging (confirmatory analyses with the exception of self–other merging)"),   note = "\U1D451\U1D3F = robust Cohen’s \U1D451; CI = bootstrapped confidence interval. The comparisons were between-groups only (i.e., there were no within-subject pre/post comparisons). One participant did not complete the Interpersonal Reactivity Index. Bold/Grey background values represent statistically significant differences between the groups on that row and variable." )) # Open in Word print(my_table, preview = "docx")  # Save in Word flextable::save_as_docx(my_table, path = "contrasts.docx")

title: Planned Contrasts Analyses (Group Comparisons)
text: make four figures comparisons significant combine one plot. function throw error dataset contains missing data. omit rows missing data now. Make figure panel 1  Make figure panel 2  Make figure panel 3  Make figure panel 4  ’s now time combine four plots one figure! Yeah!  Let’s save high-resolution/vector version figure PDF (.png format necessary).
code: Data <- na.omit(data) (EC <- nice_violin(   group = "Group",   response = "IRIEC",   data = Data,   colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),   ytitle = "Empathic Concern (from IRI)",   signif_annotation = "*",   signif_yposition = 5.2,   signif_xmin = 1,   signif_xmax = 3 )) (PD <- nice_violin(   group = "Group",   response = "IRIPD",   data = Data,   colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),   ytitle = "Personal Distress (from IRI)",   signif_annotation = "*",   signif_yposition = 5,   signif_xmin = 1,   signif_xmax = 3 )) (PR <- nice_violin(   group = "Group",   response = "QCAEPR",   data = Data,   colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),   ytitle = "Peripheral Responsivity (from QCAE)",   signif_annotation = "*",   signif_yposition = 4.2,   signif_xmin = 1,   signif_xmax = 3 )) (IOS <- nice_violin(   group = "Group",   response = "IOS",   data = Data,   colours = c("#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),   ytitle = "Self-Other Merging (from IOS)",   signif_annotation = c("***", "*", "*"),   signif_yposition = c(8.25, 7.5, 6.75),   signif_xmin = c(1, 1, 2),   signif_xmax = c(3, 2, 3) )) library(ggpubr) (figure <- ggarrange(EC, PD, PR, IOS,   labels = "AUTO",   ncol = 2, nrow = 2 )) ggplot2::ggsave("Figure 1.pdf", figure,   width = 14, height = 14,   unit = "in", dpi = 300 )

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
text: Let’s first load demo data. data set comes base R (meaning can directly type command R console). Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: install.packages("rempsyc"). Furthermore, may asked install following packages haven’t installed already (may decide install now avoid interrupting workflow wish follow tutorial beginning end): moderations simple slopes, usually want standardize (least center) variables.
code: head(mtcars) ##                    mpg cyl disp  hp drat    wt  qsec vs am gear carb ## Mazda RX4         21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.620 16.46  0  1    4    4 ## Mazda RX4 Wag     21.0   6  160 110 3.90 2.875 17.02  0  1    4    4 ## Datsun 710        22.8   4  108  93 3.85 2.320 18.61  1  1    4    1 ## Hornet 4 Drive    21.4   6  258 110 3.08 3.215 19.44  1  0    3    1 ## Hornet Sportabout 18.7   8  360 175 3.15 3.440 17.02  0  0    3    2 ## Valiant           18.1   6  225 105 2.76 3.460 20.22  1  0    3    1 library(rempsyc) pkgs <- c("effectsize", "flextable", "interactions") install_if_not_installed(pkgs) mtcars2 <- lapply(mtcars, scale) |> as.data.frame()

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
text: want look nice Dependent Variable Predictor df b* t p sr2 95% CI mpg gear 28 -0.09 -0.80 .431 .00 [0.00, 0.03] wt 28 -0.95 -8.60 < .001*** .56 [0.31, 0.80] gear × wt 28 -0.24 -2.16 .040* .04 [0.00, 0.10] Note: sr2 (semi-partial correlation squared, also known delta R-square) allows us quantify unique contribution (proportion variance explained) independent variable dependent variable, variables model. sr2 often considered better indicator practical relevance variable.
code: moderations <- nice_mod(   data = mtcars2,   response = "mpg",   predictor = "gear",   moderator = "wt" ) moderations ##   Dependent Variable Predictor df           B          t            p ## 1                mpg      gear 28 -0.08718042 -0.7982999 4.314156e-01 ## 2                mpg        wt 28 -0.94959988 -8.6037724 2.383144e-09 ## 3                mpg   gear:wt 28 -0.23559962 -2.1551077 3.989970e-02 ##           sr2     CI_lower   CI_upper ## 1 0.004805465 0.0000000000 0.02702141 ## 2 0.558188818 0.3142326391 0.80214500 ## 3 0.035022025 0.0003502202 0.09723370 (my_table <- nice_table(moderations, highlight = TRUE))

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
text: might heard “simple slopes” . mean? Essentially, means looking strength (regression coefficient) significance slope, subsetting observations high, low, average variable, typically moderating variable. bit , get clearer looking plot interaction, shows one slope observations high wt (moderating) variable, second slope low, third slope average. Let’s extract simple slopes now, including sr2. Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df b* t p sr2 95% CI mpg gear (LOW-wt) 28 0.15 1.08 .291 .01 [0.00, 0.04] gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.09 -0.80 .431 .00 [0.00, 0.03] gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.32 -1.90 .067 .03 [0.00, 0.08] specific case, interaction significant none simple slopes. means although two slopes significantly different , taken individually, slopes aren’t significantly different straight line. neat thing can add many dependent variables want. Dependent Variable Predictor df b* t p sr2 95% CI mpg gear 28 -0.09 -0.80 .431 .00 [0.00, 0.03] wt 28 -0.95 -8.60 < .001*** .56 [0.31, 0.80] gear × wt 28 -0.24 -2.16 .040* .04 [0.00, 0.10] disp gear 28 -0.07 -0.70 .492 .00 [0.00, 0.02] wt 28 0.83 7.67 < .001*** .43 [0.19, 0.67] gear × wt 28 -0.09 -0.81 .422 .00 [0.00, 0.03] hp gear 28 0.42 2.65 .013* .11 [0.00, 0.27] wt 28 0.93 5.75 < .001*** .53 [0.29, 0.77] gear × wt 28 0.15 0.96 .346 .01 [0.00, 0.07] Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df b* t p sr2 95% CI mpg gear (LOW-wt) 28 0.15 1.08 .291 .01 [0.00, 0.04] gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.09 -0.80 .431 .00 [0.00, 0.03] gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.32 -1.90 .067 .03 [0.00, 0.08] disp gear (LOW-wt) 28 0.01 0.09 .926 .00 [0.00, 0.00] gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.07 -0.70 .492 .00 [0.00, 0.02] gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.16 -0.97 .339 .01 [0.00, 0.03] hp gear (LOW-wt) 28 0.27 1.34 .190 .03 [0.00, 0.11] gear (MEAN-wt) 28 0.42 2.65 .013* .11 [0.00, 0.27] gear (HIGH-wt) 28 0.58 2.33 .027* .09 [0.00, 0.22] Pro tip: nice_mod() nice_slopes() functions take argument, can just copy-paste first change function call save time!
code: slopes <- nice_slopes(   data = mtcars2,   response = "mpg",   predictor = "gear",   moderator = "wt" ) slopes ##   Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df           B          t          p ## 1                mpg       gear (LOW-wt) 28  0.14841920  1.0767040 0.29080233 ## 2                mpg      gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.08718042 -0.7982999 0.43141565 ## 3                mpg      gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.32278004 -1.9035367 0.06729622 ##           sr2 CI_lower   CI_upper ## 1 0.008741702        0 0.03886052 ## 2 0.004805465        0 0.02702141 ## 3 0.027322839        0 0.08179662 nice_table(slopes, highlight = TRUE) # Moderations nice_mod(   data = mtcars2,   response = c("mpg", "disp", "hp"),   predictor = "gear",   moderator = "wt" ) |>   nice_table(highlight = TRUE) # Simple slopes nice_slopes(   data = mtcars2,   response = c("mpg", "disp", "hp"),   predictor = "gear",   moderator = "wt" ) |>   nice_table(highlight = TRUE)

title: Publication-ready moderations with simple slopes in R
text: Dependent Variable Predictor df b t p sr2 95% CI mpg cyl 27 -0.11 -0.72 .479 .00 [0.00, 0.01] wt 27 -0.62 -5.70 < .001*** .14 [0.02, 0.25] hp 27 -0.29 -2.40 .023* .02 [0.00, 0.06] wt × hp 27 0.29 3.23 .003** .04 [0.00, 0.10] qsec disp 27 -0.43 -1.97 .059 .07 [0.00, 0.20] drat 27 -0.33 -1.53 .138 .04 [0.00, 0.14] carb 27 -0.51 -3.32 .003** .20 [0.00, 0.41] drat × carb 27 -0.23 -1.08 .289 .02 [0.00, 0.09] applies simple slopes, time use nice_lm_slopes function. supports multiple lm models well, predictor moderator need models (dependent variable can change).
code: model1 <- lm(mpg ~ cyl + wt * hp, mtcars2) model2 <- lm(qsec ~ disp + drat * carb, mtcars2) my.models <- list(model1, model2) nice_lm(my.models) |>   nice_table(highlight = TRUE)

title: Publication-ready scatter plots in R
text: need create FIRST layer just slopes. add transparency group lines except group average emphasize group average (new argument groups.alpha).  Finally ready add SECOND layer just points top previous layer. use standard ggplot syntax .
code: # This simply copies the 'mtcars' dataset new.Data <- mtcars # That would be your "Group" variable normally # And this operation fills all cells of that column with the word # "Average" to identify our new 'group' new.Data$cyl <- "Average" # This adds the new "Average" group rows to the original data rows XData <- rbind(mtcars, new.Data) (p <- nice_scatter(   data = XData,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   has.points = FALSE,   group = "cyl",   colours = c("black", "#00BA38", "#619CFF", "#F8766D"),   # We add colours manually because we want average to be black to stand out   groups.order = c("Average", "4", "6", "8"),   # We do this to have average on top since it's the most important   groups.alpha = c(1, 0.5, 0.5, 0.5) )) # This adds 50% transparency to all lines except # the first one (Average) which is 100% library(ggplot2) p + geom_point(   data = mtcars,   size = 2,   alpha = 0.5,   shape = 16,   # We use shape 16 because the default shape 19 sometimes   # causes problems when exporting to PDF   mapping = aes(     x = wt,     y = mpg,     colour = factor(cyl),     fill = factor(cyl)   ) )

Else the next legend won't appear on the second layer!   colours = "black" )) p + geom_point(   data = mtcars,   size = 2,   alpha = 0.5,   shape = 16,   mapping = aes(     x = wt,     y = mpg,     colour = factor(cyl)   ) )

title: Publication-ready t-tests in R
text: function makes really easy get t-test results one simple, publication-ready table. Let’s first load demo data. data set comes base R (meaning can directly type command R console). Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: install.packages("rempsyc"). Furthermore, may asked install following packages haven’t installed already (may decide install now avoid interrupting workflow wish follow tutorial beginning end): Note: function relies base R t.test function, uses Welch t-test per default (see : https://daniellakens.blogspot.com/2015/01/always-use-welchs-t-test-instead-.html). use Student t-test, simply add following argument: var.equal = TRUE. Now best thing function can put dependent variables interest function call output sweet, pre-formatted table convenience. want look nice Dependent Variable t df p d 95% CI mpg -3.77 18.33 .001** -1.48 [-2.27, -0.67] cyl 3.35 25.85 .002** 1.21 [0.43, 1.97] disp 4.20 29.26 < .001*** 1.45 [0.64, 2.23] hp 1.27 18.72 .221 0.49 [-0.23, 1.21] drat -5.65 27.20 < .001*** -2.00 [-2.86, -1.12] wt 5.49 29.23 < .001*** 1.89 [1.03, 2.73] Note: d Cohen’s d, 95% CI confidence interval effect size (Cohen’s d). p p-value, df degrees freedom, t t-value.

what: Paired t test (instead of independent samples)
title: Publication-ready t-tests in R
text: Note paired t tests, need use paired = TRUE, also need data “long” format rather wide format (like ToothGrowth data set). case, group argument refers participant ID example, group/participant measured several times, thus several rows. Note R >= 4.4.0 stopped supporting paired argument formula method used internally nice_t_test(), since version 0.1.7.8, use workaround backward compatibility.
code: nice_t_test(   data = ToothGrowth,   response = "len",   group = "supp",   paired = TRUE ) |>   nice_table()

title: Publication-ready t-tests in R
text: also possible correct multiple comparisons. Note Bonferroni correction supported time (simply multiplies p-value number tests). Bonferroni automatically correct number tests. Dependent Variable t df p d 95% CI mpg -3.77 18.33 .008** -1.48 [-2.27, -0.67] cyl 3.35 25.85 .015* 1.21 [0.43, 1.97] disp 4.20 29.26 .001** 1.45 [0.64, 2.23] hp 1.27 18.72 1.326 0.49 [-0.23, 1.21] drat -5.65 27.20 < .001*** -2.00 [-2.86, -1.12] wt 5.49 29.23 < .001*** 1.89 [1.03, 2.73]
code: nice_t_test(   data = mtcars,   response = names(mtcars)[1:6],   group = "am",   correction = "bonferroni",   warning = FALSE ) |>   nice_table()

title: Publication-ready t-tests in R
text: ways t-tests format results properly, wish—example broom report packages. Examples .
code: model <- t.test(mpg ~ am, data = mtcars)

title: Publication-ready t-tests in R
text: Method Alternative Mean 1 Mean 2 M1 - M2 t df p 95% CI Welch Two Sample t-test two.sided 17.15 24.39 -7.24 -3.77 18.33 .001** [-11.28, -3.21]
code: library(broom) (stats.table <- tidy(model, conf.int = TRUE)) ## # A tibble: 1 × 10 ##   estimate estimate1 estimate2 statistic p.value parameter conf.low conf.high ##      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> ## 1    -7.24      17.1      24.4     -3.77 0.00137      18.3    -11.3     -3.21 ## # ℹ 2 more variables: method <chr>, alternative <chr> nice_table(stats.table, broom = "t.test")

title: Publication-ready t-tests in R
text: Parameter Group Mean_Group1 Mean_Group2 Difference t 95% CI (t) df p Method Alternative d 95% CI (d) mpg 17.15 24.39 -7.24 -3.77 [-11.28, -3.21] 18.33 .001** Welch Two Sample t-test two.sided -1.76 [-2.82, -0.67] report package provides quite comprehensive tables, one may request abbreviated table short argument. Parameter Group t df p Method Alternative d 95% CI (d) mpg -3.77 18.33 .001** Welch Two Sample t-test two.sided -1.76 [-2.82, -0.67] go!
code: library(report) (stats.table <- as.data.frame(report(model))) ## Welch Two Sample t-test ##  ## Parameter | Group | Mean_Group1 | Mean_Group2 | Difference |          95% CI ## ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ## mpg       |    am |       17.15 |       24.39 |      -7.24 | [-11.28, -3.21] ##  ## Parameter | t(18.33) |     p |     d |          d  CI ## ----------------------------------------------------- ## mpg       |    -3.77 | 0.001 | -1.76 | [-2.82, -0.67] ##  ## Alternative hypothesis: two.sided nice_table(stats.table, report = "t.test") nice_table(stats.table, report = "t.test", short = TRUE)

title: Publication-ready APA tables: from R to Word in 2 min
text: previous workflow pretty tedious, preparing tables R (data frames), export Excel, copy Excel Word, finally format table Word. Whenever make minor changes, take quite bit time repeat steps. Fortunately, found package suits needs nicely, flextable. However, really need tables APA style 7th edition (Times New Roman size 12, horizontal lines, double-spaced, right number decimals, etc.), made function just default settings like simplify life. many existing options APA tables. however prebuild tables specific analyses contexts provide little flexibility (yet won’t export Word). need build tables require flexibility, read !

title: Publication-ready APA tables: from R to Word in 2 min
text: Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: install.packages("rempsyc"). Furthermore, may asked install following packages haven’t installed already (may decide install now avoid interrupting workflow wish follow tutorial beginning end): function can used almost dataframe (though allow duplicate column names). ’s simple example using mtcars dataset, comes base R (meaning can try example without downloading anything). Table 1 Motor Trend Car Road Tests mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs gear carb 21.00 6.00 160.00 110.00 3.90 2.62 16.46 0.00 1.00 4.00 4.00 21.00 6.00 160.00 110.00 3.90 2.88 17.02 0.00 1.00 4.00 4.00 22.80 4.00 108.00 93.00 3.85 2.32 18.61 1.00 1.00 4.00 1.00 Note. data extracted 1974 Motor Trend US magazine. * p < .05, ** p < .01, *** p < .001
code: library(rempsyc) pkgs <- c("flextable", "broom", "report", "effectsize") install_if_not_installed(pkgs) nice_table(   mtcars[1:3, ],   title = c("Table 1", "Motor Trend Car Road Tests"),   note = c(     "The data was extracted from the 1974 Motor Trend US magazine.",     "* p < .05, ** p < .01, *** p < .001"   ) )

title: Publication-ready APA tables: from R to Word in 2 min
text: Let’s setup ‘credible’ table actual statistics demonstration. normally need bit complicated code extract relevant statistical information create dataframe suits needs.

title: Publication-ready APA tables: from R to Word in 2 min
text: dataframe looks like (notice large number decimals): Now can apply function! Term b* SE t p 95% CI (Intercept) -0.18 0.09 -2.15 .041* [-0.36, -0.01] cyl -0.11 0.15 -0.72 .479 [-0.42, 0.20] wt -0.62 0.11 -5.70 < .001*** [-0.85, -0.40] hp -0.29 0.12 -2.40 .023* [-0.53, -0.04] wt × hp 0.29 0.09 3.23 .003** [0.11, 0.47] Next, can save flextable object, can later edit, view, export another software (e.g., Microsoft Word). Breaking news! APA 7th edition actually advises using beta (β) represent standardized coefficients, instead suggests use lowercase italic b followed asterisk: b*. rempsyc follow APA recommendation version 0.1.6.1 going forward.
code: # Standardize variables to get standardized coefficients mtcars.std <- lapply(mtcars, scale) # Create a simple linear model model <- lm(mpg ~ cyl + wt * hp, mtcars.std) # Gather summary statistics stats.table <- as.data.frame(summary(model)$coefficients) # Get the confidence interval (CI) of the regression coefficient CI <- confint(model) # Add a row to join the variables names and CI to the stats stats.table <- cbind(row.names(stats.table), stats.table, CI) # Rename the columns appropriately names(stats.table) <- c("Term", "B", "SE", "t", "p", "CI_lower", "CI_upper") stats.table ##                    Term          B         SE          t            p ## (Intercept) (Intercept) -0.1835269 0.08532112 -2.1510135 4.058431e-02 ## cyl                 cyl -0.1082286 0.15071576 -0.7180977 4.788652e-01 ## wt                   wt -0.6230206 0.10927573 -5.7013627 4.663587e-06 ## hp                   hp -0.2874898 0.11955935 -2.4045781 2.331865e-02 ## wt:hp             wt:hp  0.2875867 0.08895462  3.2329593 3.221753e-03 ##               CI_lower     CI_upper ## (Intercept) -0.3585914 -0.008462403 ## cyl         -0.4174718  0.201014550 ## wt          -0.8472358 -0.398805290 ## hp          -0.5328053 -0.042174267 ## wt:hp        0.1050669  0.470106453 nice_table(stats.table) my_table <- nice_table(stats.table)

title: Publication-ready APA tables: from R to Word in 2 min
text: One can easily open table Word quick copy-pasting. Alternatively, one can save table Word specifying object name desired path. Simply change path like save . copy-paste path name, remember use “R” slashes (‘/’ rather ‘\’). Also remember specify file name .docx extension. ’s ! Simple eh?
code: print(my_table, preview = "docx") flextable::save_as_docx(my_table, path = "nice_tablehere.docx")

title: Publication-ready APA tables: from R to Word in 2 min
text: Notice provide CI_lower CI_upper column names, automatically properly format confidence interval column remove lower upper bound columns. can also see automatically formats df, b, t, p values italic. also correctly rounded row, formatted p values < .001 stripped leading zeros (correlations r, R2, sr2). Note: order work automatically, columns must named correctly. Currently function make following conversions: p, t, SE, SD, M, W, N, n, z, F, b, r, df italic; R2 sr2 italic squared, dR italic R subscript, np2 italic η subscript-p squared, ges italic η subscript-G squared, B b* (β version <= 0.1.6). seeing symbol ? title: Publication-ready APA tables: from R to Word in 2 min
text: people asked make multilevel descriptive level tables nice_table. several ways using package. straightforward, ’s attempt multiple time measurements, multiple groups, multiple dependent variables. assuming study several time measurements, make copy iris data set pretend “Time 2”. Species grouping variable. can apply simple function, however, (painstakingly) reshape data proper format. Variable T1.setosa.M T1.setosa.SD T1.versicolor.M T1.versicolor.SD T1.virginica.M T1.virginica.SD T2.setosa.M T2.setosa.SD T2.versicolor.M T2.versicolor.SD T2.virginica.M T2.virginica.SD Sepal.Length 5.01 0.35 5.94 0.52 6.59 0.64 6.01 0.35 6.94 0.52 7.59 0.64 Sepal.Width 3.43 0.38 2.77 0.31 2.97 0.32 4.43 0.38 3.77 0.31 3.97 0.32 Petal.Length 1.46 0.17 4.26 0.47 5.55 0.55 2.46 0.17 5.26 0.47 6.55 0.55 far good; ’ve managed transform data suitable format next step. data right shape (header components separated dots), can apply magic: Variable T1 T2 setosa versicolor virginica setosa versicolor virginica M SD M SD M SD M SD M SD M SD Sepal.Length 5.01 0.35 5.94 0.52 6.59 0.64 6.01 0.35 6.94 0.52 7.59 0.64 Sepal.Width 3.43 0.38 2.77 0.31 2.97 0.32 4.43 0.38 3.77 0.31 3.97 0.32 Petal.Length 1.46 0.17 4.26 0.47 5.55 0.55 2.46 0.17 5.26 0.47 6.55 0.55 find efficient way (data wrangling part), please let know. Nice result though!
code: # Setup example dataset data <- cbind(iris[c(5, 1:3)], iris[1:3] + 1) names(data)[-1] <- c(   paste0("T1.", names(data[2:4])),   paste0("T2.", names(data[2:4])) )  # Get descriptive statistics library(dplyr) descriptive.data <- data %>%   group_by(Species) %>%   summarize(across(T1.Sepal.Length:T2.Petal.Length,     list(m = mean, sd = sd),     .names = "{.col}.{.fn}"   ))  # Rename the columns so we can merge them later names(descriptive.data) <- c(   "Species", rep(c("T1.M", "T1.SD"), 3),   rep(c("T2.M", "T2.SD"), 3) )  # Extract the data by variable and measurement time T1.disp <- cbind(   descriptive.data[1, 2:3],   descriptive.data[2, 2:3],   descriptive.data[3, 2:3] ) T1.hp <- cbind(   descriptive.data[1, 4:5],   descriptive.data[2, 4:5],   descriptive.data[3, 4:5] ) T1.drat <- cbind(   descriptive.data[1, 6:7],   descriptive.data[2, 6:7],   descriptive.data[3, 6:7] ) T2.disp <- cbind(   descriptive.data[1, 8:9],   descriptive.data[2, 8:9],   descriptive.data[3, 8:9] ) T2.hp <- cbind(   descriptive.data[1, 10:11],   descriptive.data[2, 10:11],   descriptive.data[3, 10:11] ) T2.drat <- cbind(   descriptive.data[1, 12:13],   descriptive.data[2, 12:13],   descriptive.data[3, 12:13] )  # Combine Time 1 with Time 2 T1 <- rbind(T1.disp, T1.hp, T1.drat) T2 <- rbind(T2.disp, T2.hp, T2.drat) wide.data <- cbind(Variable = names(iris[1:3]), T1, T2)  # Rename variables to avoid duplicate names not allowed names(wide.data)[-1] <- paste0(   rep(c("T1.", "T2."), each = 6),   rep(descriptive.data$Species, times = 2, each = 2),   paste0(c(".M", ".SD")) )  # Make preliminary nice_table nice_table(wide.data) nice_table(wide.data, separate.header = TRUE, italics = seq(wide.data))

text: Another colleague asked, whether possible use multilevel headings, still benefiting regular automatic formatting p-values, confidence intervals, etc. challenging task implement, think ’ve got something mostly work. Demo: Dependent Variable T1.t T1.df T1.p T1.d T1.CI_lower T1.CI_upper T2.t T2.df T2.p T2.d T2.CI_lower T2.CI_upper mpg -3.77 18.33 0.00 -1.48 -2.27 -0.67 -4.67 22.72 0.00 -1.73 -2.55 -0.90 disp 4.20 29.26 0.00 1.45 0.64 2.23 5.94 26.98 0.00 1.97 1.10 2.82 Dependent Variable T1 T2 t df p d 95% CI t df p d 95% CI mpg -3.77 18.33 .001 -1.48 [-2.27, -0.67] -4.67 22.72 < .001 -1.73 [-2.55, -0.90] disp 4.20 29.26 < .001 1.45 [0.64, 2.23] 5.94 26.98 < .001 1.97 [1.10, 2.82] Let’s test adding another level heading testing. Dependent Variable Early.T1.t Early.T1.df Early.T1.p Early.T1.d Early.T1.CI_lower Early.T1.CI_upper Late.T2.t Late.T2.df Late.T2.p Late.T2.d Late.T2.CI_lower Late.T2.CI_upper mpg -3.77 18.33 0.00 -1.48 -2.27 -0.67 -4.67 22.72 0.00 -1.73 -2.55 -0.90 disp 4.20 29.26 0.00 1.45 0.64 2.23 5.94 26.98 0.00 1.97 1.10 2.82 Dependent Variable Early Late T1 T2 t df p d 95% CI t df p d 95% CI mpg -3.77 18.33 .001 -1.48 [-2.27, -0.67] -4.67 22.72 < .001 -1.73 [-2.55, -0.90] disp 4.20 29.26 < .001 1.45 [0.64, 2.23] 5.94 26.98 < .001 1.97 [1.10, 2.82]
code: T1.mpg <- nice_t_test(data = mtcars, response = "mpg", group = "am") T2.mpg <- nice_t_test(data = mtcars, response = "mpg", group = "vs") T1.disp <- nice_t_test(data = mtcars, response = "disp", group = "am") T2.disp <- nice_t_test(data = mtcars, response = "disp", group = "vs") names(T1.mpg)[-1] <- paste0("T1.", names(T1.mpg)[-1]) names(T2.mpg) <- paste0("T2.", names(T2.mpg)) names(T1.disp)[-1] <- paste0("T1.", names(T1.disp)[-1]) names(T2.disp) <- paste0("T2.", names(T2.disp)) T1 <- rbind(T1.mpg, T1.disp) T2 <- rbind(T2.mpg, T2.disp) wide.data <- cbind(T1, T2[-(1)]) nice_table(wide.data) nice_table(wide.data, separate.header = TRUE, stars = FALSE) names(wide.data)[-1] <- paste0(   rep(c("Early.", "Late."), each = 6),   names(wide.data)[-1] ) nice_table(wide.data) nice_table(wide.data, separate.header = TRUE, stars = FALSE)

title: Publication-ready violin plots in R
text: happened lots plots slight variations, made function make life easier. function, particular, serves compare 2 experimental groups (although still plot 1 group). use violin plots instead bar plots provide information space (precisely, distribution density/frequency responses, allows visually estimate normality, skewness, kurtosis). Let’s first load demo data. data set comes base R (meaning can directly type command R console). Load rempsyc package: Note: haven’t installed package yet, need install via following command: install.packages("rempsyc"). Furthermore, may asked install following packages haven’t installed already (may decide install now avoid interrupting workflow wish follow tutorial beginning end):
code: data("ToothGrowth") head(ToothGrowth) ##    len supp dose ## 1  4.2   VC  0.5 ## 2 11.5   VC  0.5 ## 3  7.3   VC  0.5 ## 4  5.8   VC  0.5 ## 5  6.4   VC  0.5 ## 6 10.0   VC  0.5 library(rempsyc) pkgs <- c("ggplot2", "boot", "psych") install_if_not_installed(pkgs) nice_violin(   data = ToothGrowth,   group = "dose",   response = "len" ) Dots = means Error bars = 95% confidence intervals Width = distribution density (frequency)

title: Publication-ready violin plots in R
text: function used give 95% bootstrapped confidence intervals (2000 bootstraps) error bars default, bootstrapping now specified explicitly. Bootstrapping non-parametric technique, meaning need respect classical parametric assumptions (normality, homoscedasticity, etc.). case ’s just nice alternative way look data. Note: bootstrapping requires number bootstraps equal higher number observations (rows). people sometimes work big datasets, ’ve added option specify specific number bootstraps option bootstraps = 2000 (change default desired value). ’ve recently work large data set (7 million observations), impractical 7 million bootstraps (, long operation), also added option turn bootstrapping completely just use regular confidence interval instead (boot = FALSE, now default).

title: Publication-ready violin plots in R
text: ’d like see available options (bit long):
code: nice_violin(   data = ToothGrowth,   group = "dose",   response = "len",   boot = TRUE,   bootstraps = 200,   ytitle = "Length of Tooth",   xtitle = "Vitamin C Dosage",   colours = c("darkseagreen", "cadetblue", "darkslateblue"),   has.ylabels = TRUE,   has.xlabels = TRUE,   xlabels = c("Low", "Medium", "High"),   ymin = 0,   ymax = 45,   yby = 15,   signif_annotation = c("*", "NS", "***"),   signif_yposition = c(30, 36, 41),   signif_xmin = c(1, 2, 1),   signif_xmax = c(2, 3, 3),   CIcap.width = 0,   alpha = 0.5,   border.colour = "black",   border.size = 1,   obs = TRUE,   has.d = TRUE,   d.x = 1.7,   d.y = 20 )

what: Special situation: Add other plot elements
title: Publication-ready violin plots in R
text: good thing function outputs ggplot object, can continue use build plot customize . instance, recently wanted add mean sample size annotations group (group sample sizes ranging 100 35,000, important know groups representative). demonstration, let’s just build multiple-groups plot earlier. simply added conventional ggplot code plot object. (first compute statistics going using:)
code: # Create our group variable: ToothGrowth$groups <- factor(sample(1:6, 60, replace = T))  # Make the plot and save it to object "p" p <- nice_violin(   data = ToothGrowth,   group = "groups",   response = "len",   border.size = 1 ) # Compute basic statistics and save to object library(psych) # Install the psych package if you don't already have it statsSummary <- describeBy(   x = ToothGrowth$len, group = ToothGrowth$groups, mat = TRUE )  # Add our annotations! (Warning: a bit more complicated code ahead!) library(ggplot2) p + annotate(   geom = "text",   # First annotation adds the average   x = seq(length(levels(ToothGrowth$groups))),   # Specifies annotations is for all groups/x-axis ticks   y = statsSummary$mean + 2,   # Puts mean at mean value on the y-axis (adds 2)   label = paste0("m =", round(statsSummary$mean, 2)) ) +   # That prints the mean on the plot   annotate(     geom = "text",     # (Second annotation adds the sample size)     x = seq(length(levels(ToothGrowth$groups))),     y = statsSummary$mean - 2,     # Puts sample size at mean value on the y-axis (substracts 2)     label = paste0("n =", round(statsSummary$n, 2))   ) # That prints the sample size on the plot

text: Easily compute t-test analyses, effect sizes, format publication-ready format. Supports multiple dependent variables . 95% confidence interval effect size (Cohen’s d).  Full tutorial: https://rempsyc.remi-theriault.com/articles/t-test
code: library(rempsyc)  t.tests <- nice_t_test(   data = mtcars,   response = c("mpg", "disp", "drat", "wt"),   group = "am" ) t.tests #>   Dependent Variable         t       df              p         d   CI_lower #> 1                mpg -3.767123 18.33225 0.001373638333 -1.477947 -2.2659732 #> 2               disp  4.197727 29.25845 0.000230041299  1.445221  0.6417836 #> 3               drat -5.646088 27.19780 0.000005266742 -2.003084 -2.8592770 #> 4                 wt  5.493905 29.23352 0.000006272020  1.892406  1.0300224 #>     CI_upper #> 1 -0.6705684 #> 2  2.2295594 #> 3 -1.1245499 #> 4  2.7329219 # Format t-test results t_table <- nice_table(t.tests) t_table # Open in Word for quick copy-pasting print(my_table, preview = "docx")  # Or save to Word flextable::save_as_docx(t_table, path = "D:/R treasures/t_tests.docx")

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology
text: Easily compute simple slopes moderation analysis, effect sizes, format publication-ready format. Supports multiple dependent variables covariates .  Full tutorial: https://rempsyc.remi-theriault.com/articles/moderation

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology
text: complicated models supported nice_slopes, one can define model traditional way feed nice_lm_slopes instead. Supports multiple lm models well, predictor moderator need models (dependent variable can change).  Full tutorial: https://rempsyc.remi-theriault.com/articles/moderation
code: model1 <- lm(mpg ~ gear * wt, mtcars) model2 <- lm(disp ~ gear * wt, mtcars) my.models <- list(model1, model2) simple.slopes <- nice_lm_slopes(my.models, predictor = "gear", moderator = "wt", standardize = TRUE) simple.slopes #>   Model Number Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df           B          t #> 1            1                mpg       gear (LOW-wt) 28  0.14841920  1.0767040 #> 2            1                mpg      gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.08718042 -0.7982999 #> 3            1                mpg      gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.32278004 -1.9035367 #> 4            2               disp       gear (LOW-wt) 28  0.01269680  0.0935897 #> 5            2               disp      gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -0.07488985 -0.6967831 #> 6            2               disp      gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -0.16247650 -0.9735823 #>            p           sr2 CI_lower    CI_upper #> 1 0.29080233 0.00874170174        0 0.038860523 #> 2 0.43141565 0.00480546484        0 0.027021406 #> 3 0.06729622 0.02732283901        0 0.081796622 #> 4 0.92610159 0.00006397412        0 0.002570652 #> 5 0.49168336 0.00354603816        0 0.022301536 #> 6 0.33860037 0.00692298820        0 0.033253212 # Format simple slopes results nice_table(simple.slopes)

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology
text: Make nice plots means time, usually randomized controlled trials several groups several time measurements. Error bars represent 95% confidence intervals adjusted within-subject variance method Morey (2008).
code: data <- mtcars names(data)[6:3] <- paste0("T", 1:4, "_some-time-variable")  plot_means_over_time(   data = data,   response = names(data)[6:3],   group = "cyl",   groups.order = "decreasing",   significance_bars_x = c(3.15, 4.15),   significance_stars = c("*", "***"),   significance_stars_x = c(3.25, 4.35),   # significance_stars_y: List with structure: list(c("group1", "group2", time))   significance_stars_y = list(c("4", "8", time = 3),                               c("4", "8", time = 4)))

title: Convenience Functions for Psychology
text: Nicely reports NA values according existing guidelines (.e, reporting absolute percentage item-based missing values, plus scale’s maximum amount missing values given participant). Accordingly, allows specifying list columns representing questionnaire items produce questionnaire-based report missing values.
code: # Create synthetic data frame for the demonstration set.seed(50) df <- data.frame(   scale1_Q1 = c(sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE), NA, NA),   scale1_Q2 = c(sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE), NA, NA),   scale1_Q3 = c(sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE), NA, NA),   scale2_Q1 = c(sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE), NA, NA),   scale2_Q2 = c(sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE), NA, NA),   scale2_Q3 = c(sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE), NA, NA),   scale3_Q1 = c(sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE), NA, NA),   scale3_Q2 = c(sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE), NA, NA),   scale3_Q3 = c(sample(c(NA, 1:6), replace = TRUE), NA, NA) )  # Then select your scales by name nice_na(df, scales = c("scale1", "scale2", "scale3")) #>                   var items na cells na_percent na_max na_max_percent all_na #> 1 scale1_Q1:scale1_Q3     3  6    27      22.22      3            100      2 #> 2 scale2_Q1:scale2_Q3     3  9    27      33.33      3            100      2 #> 3 scale3_Q1:scale3_Q3     3  8    27      29.63      3            100      2 #> 4               Total     9 23    81      28.40      9            100      2  # Or whole dataframe nice_na(df) #>                   var items na cells na_percent na_max na_max_percent all_na #> 1 scale1_Q1:scale3_Q3     9 23    81       28.4      9            100      2

what: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel
title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel
text: Easily output correlation matrix export Microsoft Excel, first row column frozen, correlation coefficients colour-coded based effect size (0.0-0.2: small (colour); 0.2-0.4: medium (pink/light blue); 0.4-1.0: large (red/dark blue)), following Cohen's suggestions small (.10), medium (.30), large (.50) correlation sizes. Based correlation openxlsx2 packages.

title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel
code: cormatrix_excel(   data,   filename,   overwrite = TRUE,   p_adjust = "none",   print.mat = TRUE,   ... )

title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel
text: data data frame filename Desired filename (path can added hand need specify extension). overwrite Whether allow overwriting previous file. p_adjust Default p-value adjustment method (default "none", although correlation::correlation()'s default "holm") print.mat Logical, whether also print correlation matrix console. ... Parameters passed correlation package (see correlation::correlation())

title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel
text: Microsoft Excel document, containing colour-coded correlation matrix significance stars, first sheet, colour-coded p-values second sheet.

title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel
text: easystats equivalent, see: correlation::cormatrix_to_excel().

title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel
text: Adapted @JanMarvin (JanMarvin/openxlsx2#286) original cormatrix_excel (now imported correlation::cormatrix_to_excel).

title: Easy export of correlation matrix to Excel — cormatrix_excel
code: # Basic example cormatrix_excel(mtcars, select = c("mpg", "cyl", "disp", "hp", "carb"), filename = "cormatrix1") #> # Correlation Matrix (pearson-method) #>  #> Parameter |      mpg |      cyl |     disp |       hp |    carb #> --------------------------------------------------------------- #> mpg       |          | -0.85*** | -0.85*** | -0.78*** | -0.55** #> cyl       | -0.85*** |          |  0.90*** |  0.83*** |  0.53** #> disp      | -0.85*** |  0.90*** |          |  0.79*** |   0.39* #> hp        | -0.78*** |  0.83*** |  0.79*** |          | 0.75*** #> carb      |  -0.55** |   0.53** |    0.39* |  0.75*** |         #>  #> p-value adjustment method: none #>  #>  #>  [Correlation matrix 'cormatrix1.xlsx' has been saved to working directory (or where specified).] #> Warning: will not open file when not interactive #> NULL cormatrix_excel(iris, p_adjust = "none", filename = "cormatrix2") #> # Correlation Matrix (pearson-method) #>  #> Parameter    | Sepal.Length | Sepal.Width | Petal.Length | Petal.Width #> ---------------------------------------------------------------------- #> Sepal.Length |              |       -0.12 |      0.87*** |     0.82*** #> Sepal.Width  |        -0.12 |             |     -0.43*** |    -0.37*** #> Petal.Length |      0.87*** |    -0.43*** |              |     0.96*** #> Petal.Width  |      0.82*** |    -0.37*** |      0.96*** |             #>  #> p-value adjustment method: none #>  #>  #>  [Correlation matrix 'cormatrix2.xlsx' has been saved to working directory (or where specified).] #> Warning: will not open file when not interactive #> NULL cormatrix_excel(airquality, method = "spearman", filename = "cormatrix3") #> # Correlation Matrix (spearman-method) #>  #> Parameter |    Ozone | Solar.R |     Wind |     Temp |   Month |   Day #> ---------------------------------------------------------------------- #> Ozone     |          | 0.35*** | -0.59*** |  0.77*** |    0.14 | -0.06 #> Solar.R   |  0.35*** |         |     0.00 |    0.21* |   -0.13 | -0.15 #> Wind      | -0.59*** |    0.00 |          | -0.45*** |   -0.16 |  0.04 #> Temp      |  0.77*** |   0.21* | -0.45*** |          | 0.37*** | -0.16 #> Month     |     0.14 |   -0.13 |    -0.16 |  0.37*** |         | -0.01 #> Day       |    -0.06 |   -0.15 |     0.04 |    -0.16 |   -0.01 |       #>  #> p-value adjustment method: none #>  #>  #>  [Correlation matrix 'cormatrix3.xlsx' has been saved to working directory (or where specified).] #> Warning: will not open file when not interactive #> NULL

what: Identify outliers based on 3 MAD — find_mad

text: Identify outliers based 3 median absolute deviations (MAD) median.

title: Identify outliers based on 3 MAD — find_mad
code: find_mad(data, col.list, ID = NULL, criteria = 3, mad.scores = TRUE)

title: Identify outliers based on 3 MAD — find_mad
text: data data frame. col.list List variables check outliers. ID ID variable like outliers identified . criteria many MAD use threshold (similar standard deviations) mad.scores Logical, whether output robust z (MAD) scores (default) raw scores. Defaults TRUE.

title: Identify outliers based on 3 MAD — find_mad
text: list dataframes outliers per variable, row numbers, based MAD. printed, provides number outliers, selected variables, outlier flagged one variable. information can obtainned using attributes() function around generated object.

title: Identify outliers based on 3 MAD — find_mad
text: function internally use scale_mad() "standardize" data based MAD median, check observation greater specified criteria (e.g., +/-3). easystats equivalent, use: performance::check_outliers(x, method = "zscore_robust, threshold = 3).

title: Identify outliers based on 3 MAD — find_mad
text: Leys, C., Ley, C., Klein, O., Bernard, P., & Licata, L. (2013). Detecting outliers: use standard deviation around mean, use absolute deviation around median. Journal Experimental Social Psychology, 49(4), 764–766. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jesp.2013.03.013

text: Test linear regression assumptions easily nice summary table.

title: Easy assumptions checks — nice_assumptions
code: nice_assumptions(model)

title: Easy assumptions checks — nice_assumptions
text: model lm() object passed function.

title: Easy assumptions checks — nice_assumptions
text: dataframe, p-value results Shapiro-Wilk, Breusch-Pagan, Durbin-Watson tests, well diagnostic column reporting many assumptions respected given model. Shapiro-Wilk set NA n < 3 n > 5000.

title: Easy assumptions checks — nice_assumptions
text: Interpretation: (p) values < .05 imply assumptions respected. Diagnostic many assumptions respected given model variable.

title: Easy assumptions checks — nice_assumptions
code: # Create a regression model (using data available in R by default) model <- lm(mpg ~ wt * cyl + gear, data = mtcars) nice_assumptions(model) #>                   Model Normality (Shapiro-Wilk) #> 1 mpg ~ wt * cyl + gear                    0.615 #>   Homoscedasticity (Breusch-Pagan) Autocorrelation of residuals (Durbin-Watson) #> 1                            0.054                                        0.525 #>   Diagnostic #> 1          0  # Multiple dependent variables at once model2 <- lm(qsec ~ disp + drat * carb, mtcars) my.models <- list(model, model2) nice_assumptions(my.models) #>                       Model Normality (Shapiro-Wilk) #> 1     mpg ~ wt * cyl + gear                    0.615 #> 2 qsec ~ disp + drat * carb                    0.013 #>   Homoscedasticity (Breusch-Pagan) Autocorrelation of residuals (Durbin-Watson) #> 1                            0.054                                        0.525 #> 2                            0.947                                        0.003 #>   Diagnostic #> 1          0 #> 2          2

title: Easy planned contrasts — nice_contrasts
text: Easily compute planned contrast analyses (pairwise comparisons similar t-tests powerful 2 groups), format publication-ready format. particular case, confidence intervals bootstraped chosen effect size (default Cohen's d).

title: Easy planned contrasts — nice_contrasts
code: nice_contrasts(   response,   group,   covariates = NULL,   data,   effect.type = "cohens.d",   bootstraps = 2000,   ... )

title: Easy planned contrasts — nice_contrasts
text: response dependent variable. group group comparison. covariates desired covariates model. data data frame. effect.type effect size type use. One "cohens.d" (default), "akp.robust.d", "unstandardized", "hedges.g", "cohens.d.sigma", "r". bootstraps number bootstraps use confidence interval ... Arguments passed bootES::bootES.

title: Easy planned contrasts — nice_contrasts
text: dataframe, selected dependent variable(s), comparisons interest, degrees freedom, t-values, p-values, Cohen's d, lower upper 95% confidence intervals effect size (.e., dR).

title: Easy planned contrasts — nice_contrasts
text: Statistical power lower standard t test compared planned contrast version two reasons: ) sample size smaller t test, cases two groups selected; b) planned contrast error term smaller standard t test based cases (source). effect size confidence interval calculated via bootES::bootES, correct contrasts covariates predictors. method uses bootstrapping, recommended set seed using reproducibility reasons (e.g., sed.seet(100)). moment support nested comparisons marginal means, comparison groups. nested comparisons, please use emmeans::contrast() directly, easystats equivalent, modelbased::estimate_contrasts(). using nice_lm_contrasts(), please use .factor() outside lm() formula, lead error.

title: Easy density plots — nice_density
text: data data frame variable dependent variable plotted. group group plot variable. colours Desired colours plot, desired. ytitle optional y-axis label, desired. xtitle optional x-axis label, desired. groups.labels groups.labels (might rename xlabels consistency functions) grid Logical, whether keep default background grid . APA style suggests using grid background, though case may find useful easily estimate slopes different groups. shapiro Logical, whether include p-value Shapiro-Wilk test plot. title desired title plot. Can put NULL remove. histogram Logical, whether add histogram breaks.auto histogram = TRUE, option set bins/breaks automatically, mimicking default behaviour base R hist() (Sturges method). Defaults FALSE. bins histogram = TRUE, option change default bin (30).

what: Nice formatting of lm models — nice_lm
title: Nice formatting of lm models — nice_lm
text: Formats output lm() model object publication-ready format.

title: Nice formatting of lm models — nice_lm
code: nice_lm(   model,   b.label = "b",   standardize = FALSE,   mod.id = TRUE,   ci.alternative = "two.sided",   ... )

title: Nice formatting of lm models — nice_lm
text: model model formatted. b.label rename default "b" column (e.g., capital B using standardized data converted Greek beta symbol nice_table function). Now attempts automatically detect whether variables standardized, , sets b.label = "B" automatically. Factor variables dummy variables (two numeric values) ignored checking standardization. argument now deprecated, please use argument standardize directly instead. standardize Logical, whether standardize data refitting model. TRUE, automatically sets b.label = "B". Defaults FALSE. Note factor variables, pseudo-betas, coefficients interpreted like Cohen's d. mod.id Logical. Whether display model number, one model. ci.alternative Alternative confidence interval sr2. can either "two.sided (default package), "greater", "less". ... arguments passed effectsize::r2_semipartial function effect size.

title: Nice formatting of lm models — nice_lm
text: formatted dataframe specified lm model, DV, IV, degrees freedom, regression coefficient, t-value, p-value, effect size, semi-partial correlation squared, confidence interval.

title: Nice formatting of lm models — nice_lm
text: effect size, sr2 (semi-partial correlation squared, also known delta R2), computed effectsize::r2_semipartial. Please read documentation function, especially regarding interpretation confidence interval. rempsyc, instead using default one-sided alternative ("greater"), use two-sided alternative. interpret sr2, use effectsize::interpret_r2_semipartial(). easystats equivalent, use report::report() lm() model object.

title: Nice formatting of simple slopes for lm models — nice_lm_slopes
code: # Make and format model model <- lm(mpg ~ gear * wt, mtcars) nice_lm_slopes(model, predictor = "gear", moderator = "wt") #>   Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df        b        t          p #> 1                mpg       gear (LOW-wt) 28 7.540509 2.010656 0.05408136 #> 2                mpg      gear (MEAN-wt) 28 5.615951 1.943711 0.06204275 #> 3                mpg      gear (HIGH-wt) 28 3.691393 1.795568 0.08336403 #>          sr2 CI_lower   CI_upper #> 1 0.03048448        0 0.08823243 #> 2 0.02848830        0 0.08418650 #> 3 0.02431123        0 0.07551496  # Make and format multiple models model2 <- lm(qsec ~ gear * wt, mtcars) my.models <- list(model, model2) x <- nice_lm_slopes(my.models, predictor = "gear", moderator = "wt") x #>   Model Number Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df         b          t #> 1            1                mpg       gear (LOW-wt) 28  7.540509  2.0106560 #> 2            1                mpg      gear (MEAN-wt) 28  5.615951  1.9437108 #> 3            1                mpg      gear (HIGH-wt) 28  3.691393  1.7955678 #> 4            2               qsec       gear (LOW-wt) 28 -1.933515 -0.8847558 #> 5            2               qsec      gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -1.742853 -1.0351610 #> 6            2               qsec      gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -1.552191 -1.2956736 #>            p        sr2 CI_lower   CI_upper #> 1 0.05408136 0.03048448        0 0.08823243 #> 2 0.06204275 0.02848830        0 0.08418650 #> 3 0.08336403 0.02431123        0 0.07551496 #> 4 0.38382325 0.02280057        0 0.11642689 #> 5 0.30945179 0.03121151        0 0.14035904 #> 6 0.20566798 0.04889790        0 0.18442862 # Get interpretations cbind(x, Interpretation = effectsize::interpret_r2_semipartial(x$sr2)) #>   Model Number Dependent Variable Predictor (+/-1 SD) df         b          t #> 1            1                mpg       gear (LOW-wt) 28  7.540509  2.0106560 #> 2            1                mpg      gear (MEAN-wt) 28  5.615951  1.9437108 #> 3            1                mpg      gear (HIGH-wt) 28  3.691393  1.7955678 #> 4            2               qsec       gear (LOW-wt) 28 -1.933515 -0.8847558 #> 5            2               qsec      gear (MEAN-wt) 28 -1.742853 -1.0351610 #> 6            2               qsec      gear (HIGH-wt) 28 -1.552191 -1.2956736 #>            p        sr2 CI_lower   CI_upper Interpretation #> 1 0.05408136 0.03048448        0 0.08823243          small #> 2 0.06204275 0.02848830        0 0.08418650          small #> 3 0.08336403 0.02431123        0 0.07551496          small #> 4 0.38382325 0.02280057        0 0.11642689          small #> 5 0.30945179 0.03121151        0 0.14035904          small #> 6 0.20566798 0.04889790        0 0.18442862          small

what: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
title: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
text: Nicely reports NA values according existing guidelines. function reports absolute percentage values specified column lists. authors recommend reporting item-level missing item per scale, well participant’s maximum number missing items scale. example, Parent (2013) writes: recommend authors () state tolerance level missing data scale subscale (e.g., “calculated means subscales participants gave least 75% complete data”) (b) report individual missingness rates scale per data point (.e., number missing values data points scale participants) maximum participant (e.g., “Attachment Anxiety, total 4 missing data points 100 observed, participant missing single data point”).

title: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
code: nice_na(data, vars = NULL, scales = NULL)

title: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
text: data data frame. vars Variable (lists variables) check NAs. scales scale names check NAs (single character string).

title: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
text: dataframe, : var: variables selected items: number items selected variables na: number missing cell values variables (e.g., 2 missing values first participant + 2 missing values second participant = total 4 missing values) cells: total number cells (.e., number participants multiplied number variables, items) na_percent: percentage missing values (number missing cells, na, divided total number cells, cells) na_max: amount missing values participant missing values selected variables na_max_percent: amount missing values participant missing values selected variables, percentage (.e., na_max divided number selected variables, items) all_na: number participants missing 100% items scale (selected variables)

title: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
text: Parent, M. C. (2013). Handling item-level missing data: Simpler just good. Counseling Psychologist, 41(4), 568-600. https://doi.org/10.1177%2F0011000012445176

title: Report missing values according to guidelines — nice_na
code: # Use whole data frame nice_na(airquality) #>         var items na cells na_percent na_max na_max_percent all_na #> 1 Ozone:Day     6 44   918       4.79      2          33.33      0  # Use selected columns explicitly nice_na(airquality,   vars = list(     c("Ozone", "Solar.R", "Wind"),     c("Temp", "Month", "Day")   ) ) #>          var items na cells na_percent na_max na_max_percent all_na #> 1 Ozone:Wind     3 44   459       9.59      2          66.67      0 #> 2   Temp:Day     3  0   459       0.00      0           0.00      0 #> 3      Total     6 44   918       4.79      2          33.33      0  # If the questionnaire items start with the same name, e.g., set.seed(15) fun <- function() {   c(sample(c(NA, 1:10), replace = TRUE), NA, NA, NA) } df <- data.frame(   ID = c("idz", NA),   open_1 = fun(), open_2 = fun(), open_3 = fun(),   extrovert_1 = fun(), extrovert_2 = fun(), extrovert_3 = fun(),   agreeable_1 = fun(), agreeable_2 = fun(), agreeable_3 = fun() )  # One can list the scale names directly: nice_na(df, scales = c("ID", "open", "extrovert", "agreeable")) #>                       var items na cells na_percent na_max na_max_percent #> 1                   ID:ID     1  7    14      50.00      1            100 #> 2           open_1:open_3     3 11    42      26.19      3            100 #> 3 extrovert_1:extrovert_3     3 17    42      40.48      3            100 #> 4 agreeable_1:agreeable_3     3 10    42      23.81      3            100 #> 5                   Total    10 45   140      32.14     10            100 #>   all_na #> 1      7 #> 2      3 #> 3      3 #> 4      3 #> 5      2

text: data data frame. predictor independent variable plotted. response dependent variable plotted. xtitle optional y-axis label, desired. ytitle optional x-axis label, desired. .points Whether plot individual observations . .jitter Alternative .points. "Jitters" observations avoid overlap (overplotting). Use one , . alpha desired level transparency. .line Whether plot regression line(s). method method use regression line, either "lm" (default) "loess". .confband Logical. Whether display confidence band around slope. .fullrange Logical. Whether extend slope beyond range observations. .linetype Logical. Whether change line types function group. .shape Logical. Whether change shape observations function group. xmin minimum score x-axis scale. xmax maximum score x-axis scale. xby much increase "tick" x-axis scale. ymin minimum score y-axis scale. ymax maximum score y-axis scale. yby much increase "tick" y-axis scale. .legend Logical. Whether display legend . legend.title desired legend title. group group plot variable colours Desired colours plot, desired. groups.order Specifies desired display order groups legend. Either provide levels directly, string: "increasing" "decreasing", order based average value variable y axis, "string.length", order shortest longest string (useful working long string names). "Defaults "none". groups.labels Changes groups names (labels). Note: applies changing order level. groups.alpha manually specified transparency desired groups slopes. Use plotting groups separately. .r Whether display correlation coefficient, r-value. r.x x-axis coordinates r-value. r.y y-axis coordinates r-value. .p Whether display p-value. p.x x-axis coordinates p-value. p.y y-axis coordinates p-value.

title: Easy scatter plots — nice_scatter
code: # Make the basic plot nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg" )  # \donttest{ # Save a high-resolution image file to specified directory ggplot2::ggsave("nicescatterplothere.pdf", width = 7,   height = 7, unit = "in", dpi = 300 ) # change for your own desired path # Change x- and y- axis labels nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   ytitle = "Miles/(US) gallon",   xtitle = "Weight (1000 lbs)" )   # Have points "jittered", loess method nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   has.jitter = TRUE,   method = "loess" )   # Change the transparency of the points nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   alpha = 1 )   # Remove points nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   has.points = FALSE,   has.jitter = FALSE )   # Add confidence band nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   has.confband = TRUE )   # Set x- and y- scales manually nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   xmin = 1,   xmax = 6,   xby = 1,   ymin = 10,   ymax = 35,   yby = 5 ) #> Warning: Removed 7 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`).   # Change plot colour nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   colours = "blueviolet" )   # Add correlation coefficient to plot and p-value nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   has.r = TRUE,   has.p = TRUE )   # Change location of correlation coefficient or p-value nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   has.r = TRUE,   r.x = 4,   r.y = 25,   has.p = TRUE,   p.x = 5,   p.y = 20 )   # Plot by group nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl" )   # Use full range on the slope/confidence band nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.fullrange = TRUE )   # Remove lines nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.line = FALSE )   # Change order of labels on the legend nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   groups.order = c(8, 4, 6) )   # Change legend labels nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   groups.labels = c("Weak", "Average", "Powerful") )  # Warning: This applies after changing order of level  # Add a title to legend nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   legend.title = "cylinders" )   # Plot by group + manually specify colours nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   colours = c("burlywood", "darkgoldenrod", "chocolate") )   # Plot by group + use different line types for each group nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.linetype = TRUE )   # Plot by group + use different point shapes for each group nice_scatter(   data = mtcars,   predictor = "wt",   response = "mpg",   group = "cyl",   has.shape = TRUE )  # }

title: Easy simple slopes — nice_slopes
text: data data frame response dependent variable. predictor independent variable moderator moderating variable. moderator2 second moderating variable, applicable. time, second moderator variable can binary variable form c(0, 1). covariates desired covariates model. b.label rename default "b" column (e.g., capital B using standardized data converted Greek beta symbol nice_table() function). Now attempts automatically detect whether variables standardized, , sets b.label = "B" automatically. Factor variables dummy variables (two numeric values) ignored checking standardization. argument now deprecated, please use argument standardize directly instead. standardize Logical, whether standardize data fitting model. TRUE, automatically sets b.label = "B". Defaults TRUE. mod.id Logical. Whether display model number, one model. ci.alternative Alternative confidence interval sr2. can either "two.sided (default package), "greater", "less". ... arguments passed lm() function models.

Please read documentation function, especially regarding interpretation confidence interval. rempsyc, instead using default one-sided alternative ("greater"), use two-sided alternative. interpret sr2, use effectsize::interpret_r2_semipartial(). easystats equivalent, use report::report() lm() model object.

title: Easy t-tests — nice_t_test
text: data data frame. response dependent variable. group group comparison. correction correction multiple comparison apply, . Default "none" option (now) "bonferroni". paired Whether use paired t-test. verbose Whether display Welch test warning . ... arguments passed t.test() function (e.g., use Student instead Welch test, change two-tail one-tail, paired-sample t-test instead independent samples).

title: Easy t-tests — nice_t_test
text: formatted dataframe specified model, DV, degrees freedom, t-value, p-value, effect size, Cohen's d, 95% confidence interval lower upper bounds.

title: Easy t-tests — nice_t_test
text: function relies base R t.test() function, uses Welch t-test per default (see : https://daniellakens.blogspot.com/2015/01/always-use-welchs-t-test-instead-.html). use Student t-test, simply add following argument: var.equal = TRUE. Note paired t tests, need use paired = TRUE, also need data "long" format rather wide format (like ToothGrowth data set). case, group argument refers participant ID example, group/participant measured several times, thus several rows. Note also R >= 4.4.0 stopped supporting paired argument formula method used internally . easystats equivalent, use: report::report() t.test() object.
